HISTORY:  New diagnosis of metastatic cancer with unknown primary.  Assess for
extent of lesions.  

COMPARISON:  CT abdomen and pelvis dated ___. 

TECHNIQUE:  Multidetector CT of the torso was performed with intravenous and
oral contrast.  Coronal and sagittal reformations were provided.  Images are
substantially degraded due to the patient's body habitus.  

FINDINGS:

CHEST: 

There are innumerable pulmonary nodules, which have an upper lobe
predilection, particularly in the left upper lobe.  The largest nodule
measures 6 mm in diameter (sequence 3 image 8).  Calcification is noted within
the right pleural cavity (sequence 3 image 24), which is likely related to the
patient's history of previous right lung surgery.  No pleural effusion.  No
pneumothorax. 

No significant mediastinal, axillary or hilar adenopathy.  Cardiac size is
normal.  No pericardial effusion. 

ABDOMEN: 

The liver is enlarged and there are innumerable low density lesions throughout
both lobes of the liver which are replacing the vast majority of the hepatic
parenchyma.  The portal vein is patent.  No intra or extrahepatic duct
dilatation.  The gallbladder is unremarkable.  There is a small amount of
ascites adjacent to the right lobe of the liver.  

The right kidney is mildly compressed anteriorly due to the enlarged liver. 
There is a subcentimeter low density lesion in the upper pole of the right
kidney, likely representing a subcentimeter cyst (sequence 5 image 31).  The
right kidney is otherwise unremarkable.  The left kidney is within normal
limits.  The adrenals and spleen are unremarkable.  The pancreas is within
normal limits. 

The small and large bowel are unremarkable.  No retroperitoneal or mesenteric
adenopathy. 

PELVIS: 

The images of the pelvis are substantially degraded secondary to the patient's
body habitus.  No pelvic masses are identified.  The bladder is unremarkable. 
The patient is status post supracervical hysterectomy.  No pelvic adenopathy. 
No free fluid within the pelvis. 

OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: 

Bilateral symmetrical sclerosis is identified on the iliac side of the
sacroiliac joints, consistent with osteitis condensans ilii.  There is severe
degenerative change within the right hip joint with joint space loss and
osteophyte formation.  No destructive osseous lesions.  

IMPRESSION:

Multiple pulmonary and hepatic metastases.  No separate primary lesion
identified.

PROCEDURE:  CT-guided drainage of a left lower quadrant collection and
repositioning of the patient's existing 8 ___ catheter in there pelvic
collection.

OPERATORS:  Dr. ___ trainee and Dr. ___
radiologist. Dr. ___ supervised the trainee during the key
components of the procedure and reviewed and agrees with the trainee's
findings.

TECHNIQUE:  The risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were
explained to the patient.  After a detailed discussion, informed written
consent was obtained.  A pre-procedure timeout using three patient identifiers
was performed per ___ protocol.


The patient was placed in a supine position on the CT scan table. Limited
preprocedure CT scan was performed to localize the collections.

A ___ wire was passed through the patient's existing 8 ___ catheter,
meeting resistance at the pigtail.  This was exchanged for a plastic
stiffener, which was advanced into the catheter.  Subsequently the catheter
was advanced further into the patient.  Subsequent CT fluoroscopic images
demonstrated appropriate catheter positioning deeper into the patient's now
collapsed existing collection.  Contrast was injected to confirm catheter
placement.

Based on the CT findings an appropriate skin entry site for the drain
placement was chosen.  The site was marked.  Local anesthesia was administered
with 1% Lidocaine solution.

Subsequently, the patient's left pelvic collection was drained.  Using
intermittent CT fluoroscopic guidance, an ___ Exodus pigtail catheter was
advanced into the collection. The plastic stiffener and the wire were removed.
The pigtail was deployed. The position of the pigtail was confirmed within the
collection via CT fluoroscopy.

Approximately 20 cc of serous fluid was aspirated with a sample sent for
microbiology and cytology evaluation. The catheter was secured by a StatLock.
The catheter was attached to bag. Sterile dressing was applied.

The procedure was tolerated well, and there were no immediate post-procedural
complications.

FINDINGS: 

VASCULAR:

There is no abdominal aortic aneurysm.  There is mild-to-moderate calcium
burden in the abdominal aorta and great abdominal arteries.  There is moderate

LOWER CHEST: There is nodular atelectasis in the posterior right costophrenic

ABDOMEN:

HEPATOBILIARY: The liver demonstrates homogenous attenuation throughout. 
There is small well-circumscribed cystic lesion in segment 7 right hepatic

RETROPERITONEUM: There are few small subcentimeter retroperitoneal periaortic

There few mildly prominent right lower quadrant, pelvic lymph nodes adjacent

Status post cystectomy, neobladder formation and right lower quadrant
diversion.  There is stable large fluid collection in the left lower abdomen,

There is percutaneous drain in the right anterior pelvis, with interval

fluid collection, without evidence of active bleeding.

REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS: The visualized reproductive organs are unremarkable.

BONES: There are degenerative changes in the lumbar spine, hips, sacroiliac
joints

SOFT TISSUES: The abdominal and pelvic wall is within normal limits.

1. Decrease in size of right lower quadrant fluid collection that has
percutaneous drain within it, with areas of high attenuation on noncontrast

2. There is large stable fluid collection in the low left abdomen, pelvis with

3. There is severe left, and moderate to severe right hydroureteronephrosis,
with delayed left nephrogram, stable from today.  Mass effect about

does not resolve, alternative etiologies including stenosis, tumor

4. Tiny hepatic lesion segment ___, attention to this area on subsequent

PROCEDURE:  CT chest without contrast.

REASON FOR EXAM:  Heavy smoking history, recent history of diagnosis
unresolved with two courses of antibiotics.

TECHNIQUE:  MDCT chest performed without IV contrast.  5-mm and 1.25-mm axial
slices were acquired with coronal and sagittal reformats.

COMPARISON:  No previous CT was available for comparison.

FINDINGS:  Dense homogeneous consolidation in the right lower lobe (3.45)
contains multiple air bronchograms. Less extensive right basal consolidation
was present on chest radiographs approximately one year ago. Diffuse nodules
throughout the remaining lungs predominate in the middle lobe, right middle
lobe and right lower lobe with relative sparing of the left lower lobe and
lung apices.  These nodules range in size from 1 to 4 mm.  A right pleural
effusion is minimal, and no pathologically enlargement of mediastinal or
axillary lymph nodes is present.The airways are widely patent to subsegmental
level bilaterally. The aorta, and heart size are normal with no pericardial
effusion. Calcification is severe in the coronary arteries, the pulmonary
artery is normal.

A fatty structure appears adherent to the lateral right atrial wall abutting
an area of atrial calcification could be an interatrial lipoma.
The left lobe of the thyroid is heterogenous and enlarged at 21 x 27 mm.

Limited review of the upper abdomen reveals multiple cystic structures in both
kidneys and high attenuation dependent material in the gallbladder most likely
small stones.

No destructive or sclerotic bone lesions are present.  Degenerative changes
throughout the thoracic spine are moderate.

IMPRESSION:
1)Severe right lower lobe consolidation, progressed or recurrent over a year,
and extensive, new diffuse lung nodules most readily explained by multifocal
bronchioalveolar carcinoma.  Alhernatively, the multiple lung nodules could
also be metastases from an extrathoracic malignancy including thyroid
carcinoma.

2)Diffuse severe coronary artery calcification.

3)Probable interatrial lipoma.

4)Bilateral renal cysts.  Small gallstones.

The case was posted to the critical findings dashboard for direct notification
of the referring physician.

INDICATION:  ___ female, positive sputum cytology and adenocarcinoma

COMPARISON:  Chest CT of ___ and chest radiograph of ___.

TECHNIQUE:  MDCT of the abdomen was performed without IV contrast. 
Subsequently, 5-mm and 1.25-mm axial slices were acquired through the chest,
abdomen, and pelvis.  Three-minute delayed images were obtained through the
abdomen.  Coronal and sagittal reformats were displayed.

CT CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST:  Again noted is dense homogeneous consolidation in
the right lower lobe containing multiple air bronchograms, which is not
significantly changed from the prior CT.  Also again noted are diffuse nodules
throughout the remaining lungs, predominantly in the right middle, right
lower, and left upper lobe with relative sparing of the apices in left lower
lobe.  There is new ground glass opacity in the left lower lobe medially.
There are several small mediastinal lymph nodes but none meeting CT criteria
for pathologic enlargement.  There is no axillary or hilar lymphadenopathy
meeting CT criteria for pathologic enlargement.  Airways are patent to the
subsegmental level.  

There is a heterogeneous 3.6 x 2.8 x 1.9 cm mass in the left lobe of the
thyroid. The heart is enlarged normal.  Unusal fat density adjacent to the
right atrium and is unchanged. There is no pericardial effusion.  There is
atherosclerotic calcification and soft plaque within the aorta, not
significantly changed from prior.  Calcification of the coronary arteries is
also noted.

CT ABDOMEN WITHOUT AND WITH IV CONTRAST:  The liver, pancreas, spleen, and
adrenal glands are unremarkable.  There is hyperdense material layering
dependently in the gallbladder, likely stones and possibly sludge.  There is
no gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid noted.  There is no
intra- or extra-hepatic biliary ductal dilatation.  

The kidneys enhance and excrete contrast symmetrically without evidence of
hydronephrosis or hydroureter.  There are several low-density
well-circumscribed parenchymal and exophytic round lesions within the
bilateral kidneys, some of which are too small to further characterize but
likely represent simple cysts.  The largest cyst is in the interpolar region
of the right kidney measuring 2.8 x 2.9 cm.  Largest cyst on the left measures
2.5 x 2.6 cm. There is a small exophytic 1 cm hyperdense cyst arising from the
upper pole of the left kidney. 

The opacified stomach and intra-abdominal loops of bowel are unremarkable. 
There is no free air or fluid in the abdomen.  No mesenteric or
retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy meeting CT criteria for pathologic enlargement
is noted.

CT PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:  The urinary bladder, distal ureters, uterus,
adnexa, and rectum are unremarkable.  There is extensive diverticulosis of the
sigmoid colon without evidence of acute diverticulitis.  There is no free
fluid in the pelvis.  No pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy meeting CT
criteria for pathologic enlargement is noted.  There is a surgical clip in the
right groin. Two calcified densities within the left buttock are noted, likely
injection granulomas.

BONE WINDOWS:  No suspicious lytic or sclerotic osseous lesion is identified. 
Degenerative changes of thoracolumbar spine is noted.  There has been prior
right shoulder surgery.

IMPRESSION:

1.  No significant change in severe right lower lobe consolidation and 
extensive diffuse small lung nodules compared to ___, which may represent
bronchoalveolar carcinoma, multifocal infection or metastatic disease with
right lower lobe infection. New ground glass opacity in the left lower lobe.

2.  No significant change in heterogeneous thyroid nodule compared to prior
CT.

3.  Diffuse coronary artery calcification and atherosclerotic plaque within
the aorta.

4.  Cholelithiasis without evidence of acute cholecystitis.

5.  Multiple bilateral renal cysts.

6.  Sigmoid diverticulosis wthout evidence of acute diverticulitis.

CT CHEST WITHOUT CONTRAST:  A 2.4 x 1.8 cm hypoattenuating left lobe thyroid
mass (2, 2) appears slightly different in configuration but stable in size as
compared to ___.  No new thyroid mass is seen within the
visualized portions of the gland.  

The heart is enlarged.  Multivessel coronary calcifications are noted.  The
previously described interatrial lipoma is unchanged.  The pulmonary artery is
top normal in size.  There is no pericardial effusion.   Small scattered
mediastinal nodes in the AP window and paratracheal stations are not
pathologically enlarged by CT size criteria.  There is no significant hilar,
or axillary lymphadenopathy.  A prominent thoracic aorta demonstrates moderate
calcifications involving the ascending aorta, the arch, arch, as well as the
descending aorta without aneurysmal dilatation.  The thoracic aortic
intramural thrombus as identified on ___, contrast-enhanced study
cannot be assessed on current noncontrast study.  Punctate calcifications are
noted in the arch vessel origins.  

There is subtle and diffuse increase in parenchymal attenuation in the lungs. 
Moderate centrilobular emphysema is present.  There are bronchial and
peribronchial nodules with ground-glass halos, predominating upper and middle
lobes, more severe as compared to ___.  These changes also involve
the right lower lobe, consistent with an infectious process.  In addition, the
dorsal right lower lobe reticular opacities interspersed with areas of
consolidation appear similar to ___, favoring a chronic process.  There
is no pleural effusion.  Central airways are patent.

Limited subdiaphragmatic evaluation reveals stable multiple bilateral renal
cysts.  A sub-2-mm nonobstructive right renal stone is unchanged.  Symmetric
lateral conal fascial thickening is not changed since prior exams.  Extensive
infradiaphragmatic aortic calcifications are again noted.  Displacement of
intimal calcification suggestive of chronic abdominal aortic dissection (2,
54) is unchanged.  

Moderate spondylosis, disc space narrowing and vacuum phenomenon are noted in
the lower thoracic and upper lumbar spine.  Median sternotomy wires are noted.

IMPRESSION:
1.  Increased bronchial and peribronchial nodules with ground-glass halos
since ___, predominating upper and middle lobes, most consistent
with infection.
2.  Stable right lower lobe reticular opacities with areas of consolidation
and widespread nodules predominantly involving the right upper and middle
lobes, consistent with known bronchioalveolar cell carcinoma.
3.  Stable large left thyroid mass.
4.  Stable abdominal aortic intimal calcification displacement.
5.  Stable renal cysts.  Miniscule nonobstructive right renal calculus.
6.  Moderate emphysema.

INDICATION:  In need of heparin.  Rule out metastatic disease.

TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous helical acquisition through the chest was performed
without intravenous contrast.  A 1.25- and 5-mm axial and sagittal and
coronally reformatted images were created.

FINDINGS:  Diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities and bronchiolar nodules,
and dense consolidations within the lingula and right middle lobe worsened
progressively over the past five months and there are several new lesions of
each variety.  The most extensive and longstanding consolidation, in the right
lower lobe basal segments is largely unchanged over more than a year, while
progressive intralobular septal thickening in the superior segment, likely
reflecting lymphangitic spread of tumor, has spread.  Diffuse moderately
severe centrilobular emphysema is unchanged.  

Mild cardiomegaly, a left atrial intramural lipoma, dense atherosclerotic
calcification of the coronary arteries, aortic arch and descending aorta are
all unchanged.  Numerous small mediastinal lymph nodes are stable in number
and size, without mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy.  The pleural and
pericardial surfaces are normal.  The trachea and bronchi to segmental levels
are patent.

No lesions suspicious for malignancy are noted in the imaged chest cage. 
Median sternotomy wires are unchanged. Multilevel degenerative changes noted
throughout the spine.

Although this study was not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, images
of the upper abdomen demonstrate low-density lesions within the kidneys
bilaterally consistent with renal cysts.  Gallstones are identified within the
gallbladder.


IMPRESSION:

1.  Interval worsening of diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities,
bronchiolar nodules and dense consolidation within the lingula and right
middle lobe. After review of multiple recent prior chest x-rays and CTs, these
findings can all be explained by worsening bronchioalveolar carcinoma, given
the absence of any change rapid enough to suggest pneumonia.  Of course
pneumonia might be present and unrecognized, and treatment should be made on
the basis of clinical findings.

2.  Stable mild cardiomegaly.

3.  Moderate emphysema.

4.  Cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.

These findings were posted to the online record of critical imaging results on
___ at 7pm.

HISTORY:  ___ woman, with non-small cell lung cancer, now with
increased shortness of breath and hypoxia.  Evaluate for infiltrate or fluid
overload.

COMPARISON:  Multiple prior chest radiographs with the latest on ___ and also CT chest on ___.

SINGLE PORTABLE CHEST RADIOGRAPH:  There is a massive right pleural effusion
with a small remnant right upper lung remaining aerated.  Interstitial opacity
is noted in the right lung which may be due to crowding and edema, although
lymphangiitic spread of tumor is not excluded.  A larger geogrpahic area of
consolidation is noted in the left mid and lower lung.  Given the history of
bronchoalveolar cell carcinoma, this could represent an extension of that
process though a superimposed infectious process is not excluded.  Median
sternotomy wires are intact.

IMPRESSION:  Interval enlargement of the now massive right pleural effusion.
